documents.title: What should I do if the e-sign link shows an error?
documents.content:
Check the account stage first:
•	If at "Application Completed": The customer must authorize their debit card via the online portal at www.ticktockloans.com
•	If at "Card Declined": They need to reattempt verification via the portal
•	If at "Underwriting": The application is under review
•	If still at "e-sign": Test the link. If the issue persists, ask the customer to clear their cache and try again. Escalate with a screenshot if necessary.

documents.title: What is the Right to Withdraw (RTW) process?
documents.content:
The customer can withdraw from the agreement within 14 days of the loan being funded. This period begins the day after the loan is funded. Once a customer has withdrawn, they have 30 days to repay the balance. This balance will accrue daily interest at a rate of 0.8% per day, based on the outstanding principal.
You should set a repayment date within the 30-day period via the Accounts tab in the Schedule section. Once the loan has been settled, raise a "Customer Service -- Withdrawal from Agreement" task. After full RTW compliance, the loan entry will be removed from the customer's credit file with the credit reference agencies.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: I've received the transaction response: "Transaction Success" -- what does this mean?
documents.content: This means that the transaction verification or payment was successful. Either the payment has been taken, or the verification has completed as expected.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: I've received the transaction response: "Transaction declined by authorization system" -- what does this mean?
documents.content: This typically refers to R1: Revocation of Authorisation, meaning the cardholder has requested to stop all recurring payment transactions. You should contact the customer to confirm whether they have cancelled all transactions. This response applies to VISA
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: The customer says the application was made fraudulently and not by them. What should I do?
documents.content:
When taking the initial details of an alleged fraudulent application, make sure to record the following information on the system:
•	Contact telephone number
•	Email address
•	Whether they recognise or hold the current bank details on the account
If the customer does not recognise the bank account, advise them to report it to their bank and request an investigation into how the account was opened in their name. We will need a copy of the letter the bank issues once their investigation is complete before we can consider closing the account.
If the bank account does belong to the customer, we will still require written confirmation from the bank stating that fraudulent transactions occurred and were investigated. In such cases, we expect the bank to reimburse the customer, who can then return the funds to us. We will also require a letter from the bank in order to write off any remaining interest.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What is the Debt Respite Scheme?
documents.content:
The Debt Respite Scheme, also known as Breathing Space, is a UK government initiative that offers individuals temporary protection from creditors while they seek debt advice or mental health treatment.
There are two types:
•	Standard Breathing Space -- lasts for 60 days
•	Mental Health Crisis Breathing Space -- lasts for the duration of the treatment, plus an additional 30 days, even if this exceeds 60 days
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What stage should I use for an account under the Debt Respite Scheme?
documents.content:
Use On Hold -- 2 Months for a standard breathing space
Use On Hold -- Vulnerable Customer for a Mental Health breathing space

In both cases, make sure to add a task to review the account in 60 days. The Insolvency Service typically informs us when the hold expires.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Is interest added while the account is in Breathing Space?
documents.content: No. Interest, fees, and charges are frozen while the account is in Breathing Space.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Right to Withdraw (RTW) Process
documents.content:
If a customer wishes to withdraw from their loan agreement, they must inform us within 14 days of the loan being funded. This 14-day period starts the day after the loan is funded.
The customer can notify us of their intention to withdraw either verbally or in writing.
The customer has 30 days from the date they notify us of their intention to withdraw to repay:
The amount borrowed, plus
The daily interest accrued up to the date the repayment is made.
Ask the customer to confirm the exact date they intend to make the repayment.
Create a new payment schedule for that date.
Set yourself a follow-up task on the same date to check whether the payment was made and follow up if necessary.
If the Customer Can’t Confirm a Date schedule the repayment for the 30th day after the withdrawal notification.
If the customer is unhappy with a card payment being scheduled, switch the payment method to bank transfer to avoid automated card collection attempts.
The balance will remain due, and the customer will continue to receive payment reminders as part of the usual communication cycle. If unpaid, the account will flow into the standard collections strategy.

documents.title: Interest Query
documents.content:
Process Overview

Refer to the customer’s original loan schedule and explain the Total Amount Payable (TAP) they agreed to at the start of their loan.
Let them know that this amount reflects what they would repay if all payments were made on time, with no changes to their repayment dates.
If the TAP has increased due to changes in payment behaviour, explain why:
Interest accrues daily at a rate of 0.8% on the outstanding principal.
Any missed payments, changes in payday, or reduced payments may lead to an increase in the total interest charged.
Reassure them that interest is capped at 100% of the amount borrowed — this is a rule set by our regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA).
Help the customer understand how they can reduce their interest:

The more they pay, the less interest is charged, as the balance decreases.
Even nominal payments (small amounts) can help reduce the interest if made within the interest-charging period.
If the customer expresses frustration (e.g., “You’re ripping me off” or “You’re like loan sharks”), respond calmly and clearly:

We are a regulated lender, authorised by the FCA.
We follow all legal rules on interest and have clearly outlined the terms in the agreement the customer signed.
We do not charge more than the 100% cap, and customers have control over how much interest builds up by making timely or early payments.
Offer to help them explore ways to settle early or reduce their repayment burden.

documents.title: Fraud Process
documents.content:
Process Overview:

Customer confirms that the bank details are not theirs:

If a customer contacts us to say they didn’t apply for the loan — often after receiving a default notice or spotting it on their credit file — follow these steps:
Verify Identity & Cross-Check Details
Ask the customer to confirm their full name, email address, contact number, and bank account details.
Compare these to what’s recorded on the account.
Outcome Based on Matching Details
If the email, phone number, and bank details match:
This likely indicates the customer, or someone close to them, made the application.
The customer would usually remain liable.
If you’re uncertain, escalate to the Fraud Specialist – Zoe Quick.
If any details do not match, especially the bank details:
Record the customer's correct contact details in the system for follow-up.
Advise the customer to report the loan as fraudulent to the bank used on the application.
The bank must investigate and provide a written response confirming the findings.
Hold the Account
Place the account on hold for 30 days while waiting for bank confirmation.
After 30 days or upon receipt of the bank’s response, escalate to Zoe Quick for fraud investigation.
Customer Confirms All Details Are Correct – But Denies Applying

If the customer confirms that all details on the loan are correct, but insists they didn’t apply:
Advise Immediate External Reporting
Instruct the customer to report the incident to:
Their bank
Action Fraud
The police (to obtain a crime reference number)
Request Supporting Evidence
We require a letter from the bank confirming that the loan funds were deposited and withdrawn by a third party without the customer’s consent.
This confirmation must be in writing and clearly state that the transaction was fraudulent.
Fraud Outcome Handling

Once confirmed in writing:
The customer will be expected to repay the original loan amount (principal), since the funds were received.
The business will then write off any interest that accrued.
This aligns with our policy where fraud is proven and funds are reimbursed by the bank.

documents.title: Breathing Space Workflow
documents.content:
Step 1: Identify Eligibility for Breathing Space
Trigger Event: 
•	Consider breathing space if a customer discloses financial hardship, or is identified, or discloses as vulnerable.
Initial Assessment: 
•	Review the customer's circumstances to determine if breathing space is suitable. Serious vulnerabilities, particularly health or mental health concerns, should be assigned to the Vulnerability Specialist (VS) - Zoe Quick.
Triggers for Referral to  Vulnerability Specialist (VS)
Please note: If the customer displays any of the following triggers, please note the account and assign to the Vulnerability Specialist. If the customer does not display any of the triggers below, then continue to step 2
Direct Disclosure of Health Conditions
•	The customer mentions a diagnosed mental health or physical health condition (e.g., depression, anxiety, cancer) that affects their ability to manage finances or respond to communications.
•	They discuss ongoing medical treatment or challenges that may impact their financial stability.
Mentions of Suicide or Self-Harm
•	If a customer mentions suicide, self-harm, or hints at thoughts of ending their life,
References to Significant Health Events
•	They mention a recent major health event, such as surgery, hospitalisation, or a new serious diagnosis, impacting their ability to meet financial obligations.
•	Statements like “I just got out of the hospital” or “I’ve been dealing with a serious health issue” can serve as indicators.
Bereavement
•	The customer mentions experiencing the recent loss of a loved one, which could impact their emotional and financial stability.
•	Statements like “I’m struggling after the loss of [family member]” or “I’ve just lost someone close to me” are strong indicators of vulnerability.
Family or Caregiver Involvement
•	A family member or caregiver emails on behalf of the customer, explaining that the customer has health or cognitive issues affecting their ability to manage the account.
•	The customer mentions they need someone’s help due to health-related challenges, signalling potential vulnerability.
Step 2 : Implement and Monitor Breathing Space
Income and Expenditure Form:
•	Send  a copy of the income and expenditure form to the customer at the start of the 14-day hold.
•	Request evidence, where appropriate,  of any change in circumstances (e.g., job loss, reduced income).
Hold Collections Activities: 
•	Pause collections activities for the initial 14-day breathing space period and move the account to a new stage labelled " On Hold - Pending Evidence”
Customer Communication: 
•	Send  confirmation Email - Account on Hold for 14 Days with Request for Evidence and I&E Completion or Email - Account on Hold for 14 Days with Request to Complete I&E Only (as appropriate) to the customer confirming they are in a hold stage and set a follow-up date for the 14-day review. 
Step 3: Review and Extend if Necessary	
Breathing Space Review: 
•	Before the end of the initial 14-day period, assess the customer’s financial situation based on the income and expenditure form and any additional evidence provided. 
•	Note: If at this stage the customer is deemed to be financially vulnerable, then please refer the account to a line manager who will determine whether or not a vulnerability flag should be added to the account
Follow-Up for Unreturned Forms: 
•	If the customer has not returned their income and expenditure form within the 14 days, contact them to remind them of the request, send  Chaser Email for Evidence and I&E Request or Chaser Email for I&E Completion Only (as appropriate) . Provide an additional 14 days for them to return the form. Send a second chaser email at 21 days Second Chaser Email for Evidence and I&E Request (Sent at 21 Days) or Second Chaser Email for I&E Completion Only (Sent at 21 Days)
Step 4: Closure
End Breathing Space:
•	If the customer’s financial position has improved or a repayment plan can be agreed based the income and expenditure provided by the customer conclude the breathing space period, move the account out of the " On Hold - Pending Evidence " stage, and outline next steps for resuming payments.
Unreturned Income and Expenditure: 
•	If the requested completed income and expenditure form or evidence of change in circumstances is not received within the extended 14-day period, return the account to the normal collections workflow and send Email - Hold Expired, Account Returning to Arrears Flow to the customer advising that the breathing space period has ended.

documents.title: Breathing Space Workflow - Health or Mental Health
documents.content:
Step 1: Identify Eligibility for Breathing Space
Trigger Event: 
•	Customer discloses is identified or discloses as health or mental health vulnerable.
Step 2 : Implement and Monitor Breathing Space
Debt and Mental Health Evidence Form: For cases indicating mental health vulnerability:
•	Vulnerability Specialist (VS) completes a Vulnerable Customer Risk Identification Checklist (Appendix A)
•	Send  a copy of the Debt and Mental Health Evidence Form (DMHEF) – (Appendix B) and Debt and Mental Health Evidence Form Consent (Appendix C)  for the customers mental health professional to complete.
•	Send a copy of the income and expenditure form for the customer to complete. 
•	Request any other evidence, where appropriate,  of any change in circumstances (e.g., job loss, reduced income).
•	. Send email 86 – Mental Health Issue Vulnerable Customer
Hold Collections Activities: 
•	Apply an initial  30-day hold which will pause all collections activities and move the account to a new stage labelled "Stage: On Hold - Vulnerable."
Customer Communication: 
•	Send “Breathing Space” Send email 86 – Mental Health Issue Vulnerable Customer to the customer confirming they are in the breathing space stage and set a follow-up date for the 30-day review.
Step 3: Review and Extend if Necessary
Breathing Space Review: 
•	Before the end of the initial 30-day period, assess the customer’s situation based on the DMHEF,  income and expenditure form and any additional evidence provided. 
Follow-Up for Unreturned Forms: 
•	If the customer has not returned their income and expenditure form within the 30 days, contact them to remind them of the request. Send  30-Day Chaser Email - Reminder – Supporting Information Needed for Your Account.  Provide an additional 30 days for them to return the information. Send a second chaser email at 45 days 45-Day Chaser Email - Final Reminder – Supporting Information Needed to Continue Account Hold Continued Vulnerability Assessment: 
•	The Vulnerability Specialist will reassess serious mental health cases to determine if additional support (such as an extended forbearance plan, write off) is needed.
Step 4: Closure
End Breathing Space:
•	If the customer’s position has improved, conclude the breathing space period, move the account out of the " Stage: On Hold - Vulnerable " stage, and outline next steps for resuming payments.
Unreturned Income and Expenditure: 
•	If the requested completed income and expenditure form or evidence of change in circumstances is not received within the extended 30-day period, return the account to the normal collections workflow and send email 163 - Breathing Space Expiry to the customer advising that the breathing space period has ended.

documents.title: How do I calculate interest?
documents.content:
Convert the percentage to a decimal:

0.8% = 0.008

Multiply the decimal by the amount:

£100 × 0.008 = £0.80

💡 Final Answer:

0.8% of £100 is £0.80 (per day)

documents.title: TEXAS - Vulnerable Customers
documents.content:
TEXAS is a widely used model designed to help frontline staff identify and respond appropriately to signs of customer vulnerability during conversations — especially when disclosures are made.

Each letter in TEXAS represents a step to guide the interaction:

🔹 T – Thank the customer
Acknowledge and thank the customer for sharing something personal. This builds trust and shows empathy.
Example:
"Thank you for letting me know, I really appreciate you sharing that with me."

🔹 E – Explain how the information will be used
Let the customer know why you're asking certain questions and how the information will help. This encourages openness and reassures them their data is handled appropriately.
Example:
"This is just so we can understand your situation better and make sure we support you in the right way."

🔹 X – eXplicit consent
Get clear permission to record and use the information disclosed, especially if it will impact how their account is handled.
Example:
"Is it okay if I make a note of what you've told me today so we can make sure your account reflects the right level of support?"

🔹 A – Ask relevant questions
Ask only appropriate, respectful follow-up questions to better understand their needs — without probing unnecessarily.
Focus on the impact, not the condition.
Example:
"How is this currently affecting your ability to manage your account or make payments?"

🔹 S – Signpost or support
Offer appropriate support based on what they’ve shared — this could include:

Applying collections hold or breathing space

Referring to the vulnerabilities specialist (Zoe Quick)

Offering adjusted communication or repayment options

Signposting to external organisations (e.g. Mind, StepChange, Samaritans)

✅ Use TEXAS when:
A customer discloses a mental health, financial, or life-impacting condition.

You suspect vulnerability based on what they say, how they say it, or how they behave.

You want to build a complete picture before applying any account-level support or escalation.

documents.title: What is the cooling-off period?
documents.content:
The cooling-off period is a set amount of time that must pass between loans once a previous loan has been repaid. During this time, any new applications will be automatically declined, in line with our repeat lending policy.
The following applies:
•	Between the 1st and 2nd loan – 30-day cooling-off period
•	Between the 2nd and 3rd loan – 30-day cooling-off period

documents.title: Do we offer top-up loans?
documents.content: No, we do not offer top-up loans. Customers are also subject to a cooling-off period, which varies depending on how many loans they’ve had previously. If a customer wishes to repay their loan and reapply, they will need to take this condition into account.

documents.content:
Lead Purchased
– The customer’s application has been sourced from an online broker and purchased by TTL.
E-sign Sent

Application Completed
– The customer has signed the agreement and now needs to complete debit card verification.
Underwriting
– The application is currently being assessed by the underwriting team.
Offer Sent
– Affordability checks are complete, and a new loan offer has been sent. The customer must re-sign the e-agreement.
Signed Off
– All assessment checks have passed, and the loan has been approved.
Funds Processing
– The loan is in the process of being sent to the customer.
Funds Sent
– Funds have been successfully credited to the customer’s account.
Collections – Missed Instalment
– The customer has missed their next scheduled payment.
Collections M0
– The customer has missed one payment.
Collections M1
– The customer has missed two payments. A 28-day notice for default may be issued at this stage.
Collections M2
– The customer has missed two or more payments. Communications about referral to a Debt Collection Agency (DCA) begin here.
Collections Review
– The account is being reviewed and prepared for referral to external debt collection.
External Collections – Referred
– The account has been passed to external debt collectors (typically in the order: CRS > UK Search > Digital DRA).
External Collections – Returned
– The account has been returned to us by the external debt collectors.

documents.title: What is Bankruptcy?
documents.content:
Bankruptcy is a legal process designed to help individuals who can’t repay their debts. It gives you a fresh financial start by writing off most of your unsecured debts, but it also comes with serious consequences and restrictions.

📝 How do you apply?
In the UK, you can apply for bankruptcy online through the government’s Insolvency Service. You don’t need to go to court unless someone else is making you bankrupt. It’s a big decision, so it’s important to get advice before applying.

💷 How much does it cost?
As of now, it costs £680 to apply for bankruptcy. This fee must be paid before your application can be submitted, although payment plans may be available in some cases.

👥 Who manages your bankruptcy?
Once your bankruptcy is approved, it is managed by an Official Receiver – a person who works for the Insolvency Service. They’ll review your finances and may take control of certain assets to help repay your debts. In some cases, a Trustee may also be appointed to handle this.

⚠️ What restrictions does bankruptcy create?
When you're bankrupt, there are several restrictions you must follow, including:

You can’t borrow more than £500 without telling the lender you’re bankrupt.

You can’t act as a company director without court permission.

You must cooperate fully with the Official Receiver and provide any information they request.

Your credit file will show the bankruptcy for 6 years, which can make getting credit, renting, or even some jobs more difficult.

Your assets may be sold, and you could be asked to make monthly payments for up to 3 years if you have disposable income.

📌 Important: Bankruptcy can be life-changing, so it’s always best to speak to a free debt adviser before applying. They can help you explore all your options and make the best choice for your situation.

documents.title: What happens if a customer goes bankrupt?
documents.content:
You’ll be notified
If a customer is made bankrupt, you’ll usually receive a notice from the Official Receiver or see it on the Insolvency Register. Alterntively, the customer may make you aware directly.

Stop all contact and collection
You must stop chasing the customer for payment — no calls, emails, letters, or legal action. Bankruptcy protection means you're legally not allowed to pursue the debt.

Send a Proof of Debt
You can submit a claim to the Official Receiver (or Trustee) showing how much you’re owed, with any evidence (like statements or contracts).

Wait for updates
The Receiver will deal with the customer’s assets. If there’s money left after priority debts and fees, you might get a small payment (called a dividend), though this is rare.

Debt is written off
After 12 months, bankruptcy usually ends. Most unsecured debts (like loans or credit cards) are written off. You can’t chase the customer after this.

documents.title: Bankruptcy Procedure
documents.content:
When a customer informs us they have been made bankrupt or are going through bankruptcy proceedings, follow the steps below:

Gather Key Information:

Full name of the court where the hearing is scheduled or has taken place.

Date of the bankruptcy hearing or date the order was made.

Bankruptcy order number (if known).

Check the Insolvency Register:

Visit the Insolvency Service website to verify if the order has been registered:
🔗 https://www.insolvencydirect.bis.gov.uk/eiir/

If listed, copy and paste the exact URL of the customer’s listing onto their account notes.

Update Account Status:

Change the customer’s stage to: On Hold – IVA/Bankruptcy.

Request Documentation:

Inform the customer that we require formal confirmation of the bankruptcy order (e.g., court letter or order document).

Make them aware that this must be received within 21 days to maintain the hold status on their account.

documents.title: How can a customer stop the default notice being registered on thier credit file?
documents.content:
To prevent the default notice from being recorded with the credit reference agencies, the customer must either:

Settle the balance stated in the letter by the date noted in the default notice. (Note: the balance in the letter may differ from the current outstanding balance, as interest has accrued since the letter was issued.)

Make a partial payment and agree for the remaining balance to be cleared either in full by a later date or through an affordable repayment arrangement. 

Note: If the amount stated in the default notice is not settled in full by the deadline, interest will continue to accrue according to the new schedule and will be payable.

documents.title: Debt Relief Order
documents.content:
A Debt Relief Order (DRO) is a formal insolvency tool designed for individuals with low income, minimal assets, and relatively small unsecured debts who are unable to repay their creditors. DROs provide a structured mechanism for managing qualifying debts while offering a clear path to debt write-off.

Key Features:

Debt Eligibility: Unsecured debts, including credit cards, personal loans, overdrafts, utility arrears, and other qualifying debts. Current debt limit: £30,000 (England & Wales).

Eligibility Criteria:

Total qualifying debts ≤ £30,000

Limited assets (generally no more than £2,000, excluding certain essential items)

Low disposable income (typically less than £75 per month after essential outgoings)

Must not have had a DRO in the past six years

Duration: Standard DRO period is 12 months. If circumstances remain unchanged, qualifying debts are written off at the end of this period.

Credit Impact: DROs remain on the individual’s credit file for six years, affecting future credit applications.

Application Process:

Must be completed through an approved intermediary (debt adviser from an approved organisation).

A one-off fee of £90 is payable before submission.

Effect During DRO: Creditors included in the DRO cannot pursue repayment while the order is active.

Considerations for Staff:

DROs are suitable only for those meeting strict eligibility criteria; staff should verify circumstances carefully.

While DROs provide debt relief, they have long-term implications for the customer’s credit rating and financial options.

Staff should advise customers of alternative solutions if DROs are not appropriate.

documents.title: Handling Customer DRO Notifications
documents.content:
Purpose:
To ensure customer Debt Relief Orders (DROs) are recorded accurately and accounts are managed correctly in line with our internal processes and regulatory requirements.

Procedure:

Customer Notification:

If a customer contacts us to advise they have been approved for a DRO, the agent should:

Record the DRO reference number.

Record the DRO order date.

Record the official receiver or intermediary handling the DRO.

Verification:

If the DRO has been formally made, the agent must verify it on the Insolvency Service Register:

Insolvency Service Register

Copy and paste the verification information into the customer notes.

Account Management:

Move the account to the IVA/Bankruptcy stage in the system.

A task will automatically be raised for the Back Office team to action at a later date.

Notes:

Ensure all relevant information is recorded clearly in the customer notes.

Do not attempt to take further collection action on accounts under an active DRO.

Outcome:
Following this procedure ensures compliance, accurate record-keeping, and that the customer’s account is managed appropriately while under a DRO.

documents.title: Calculating Daily Interest
documents.content:
Purpose:
To provide staff with a clear process for explaining how interest is applied and to calculate the daily interest charge for customer accounts.

Interest Rate:

We charge 0.8% per day on the outstanding principal balance.

Daily Interest Calculation:

Identify the outstanding principal on the customer account.

Multiply the principal by 0.8% (0.008) to calculate the daily interest charge.

Formula:

Daily Interest = Outstanding Principal × 0.008


Example Calculations:

Principal (£)	Daily Interest (£)
300	            2.40
500	            4.00
750	            6.00
1,000	        8.00
1,500	        12.00

Using the Table/Formula on Calls:

If a customer asks how much interest will be applied each day, staff can either:

Use the table for quick reference, or

Apply the formula to calculate the exact amount for the outstanding balance.

Notes:

Interest is calculated daily based on the current outstanding principal.

Do not include previously accrued interest when calculating daily interest — only use the current principal.

Ensure all calculations and explanations are clearly noted in the customer account.

documents.title: Early Settlements
documents.content:
Purpose:
To explain how early settlements work and provide staff with a clear process to follow when customers request to pay their loan in full before the end of the agreed duration.

Key Points:

Customers can settle their loan early by paying:

The outstanding principal, and

The interest accrued up to the settlement date.

The settlement figure provided is valid only on the day it is quoted.

If payment is not made on the same day, the settlement figure will increase daily at a rate of 0.8% of the outstanding principal.

Advise the customer:

“This figure is valid for today only. If payment is not made today, the settlement figure will increase tomorrow by 0.8% of the outstanding principal.”

Note the account with the settlement figure given and the date.

Formula for Daily Settlement Increase:

Daily Increase = Outstanding Principal × 0.008


Example:

Outstanding principal: £1,000

Daily increase: £1,000 × 0.008 = £8.00

If the customer does not pay today, the quoted settlement figure will increase by £8.00 tomorrow.

Important Notes for Staff:

Always remind customers that early settlement saves them from paying further future interest, but the figure changes daily.

Ensure all settlement quotes and customer communications are recorded in the notes.

Do not attempt to fix a settlement figure beyond the day it is quoted.

documents.title: Contacting Customers in Insolvency
documents.content:
No. Once a customer has entered an approved form of insolvency (e.g. Debt Relief Order, Individual Voluntary Arrangement, Bankruptcy, or Debt Management Plan through an appointed provider), we must not work directly with the customer regarding repayment of their debt.

Procedure for Staff:

Identify Insolvency Status:

Confirm the form of insolvency (e.g. DRO, IVA, Bankruptcy, DMP).

Record all relevant details in the customer notes (reference number, order date, name of Insolvency Practitioner/Official Receiver/DMP provider).

Verification:

Where applicable, verify on the Insolvency Register:
Insolvency Service Register

Copy and paste confirmation into customer notes.

Account Handling:

Move the account to the IVA/Bankruptcy stage in the system.

A back-office task will automatically be raised for further handling.

Communication:

Do not discuss repayment or collection directly with the customer.

Politely explain that all communications will now be managed via their appointed Insolvency Practitioner/Official Receiver/DMP provider.

Script Example for Agents:

“As your account is now under an approved form of insolvency, we’re not able to discuss repayment directly with you. From this point forward, all matters will be handled by your Insolvency Practitioner/Official Receiver, and we will work directly with them on your account.”

Key Compliance Note:
Contacting customers directly to seek repayment after insolvency has been approved may breach regulatory obligations and consumer duty principles. All communication must go through the appointed insolvency representative.

documents.title: Insolvency Orders Made Before Loan Approval
documents.content:
Scenario:
A customer advises (or it is identified) that they had an insolvency order (e.g. DRO, IVA, Bankruptcy) in place before they took out the loan.

Key Point:

If the insolvency order was already made before the loan agreement was taken out, the customer’s current loan is not included in that insolvency.

This means the customer remains liable for repayment under the original loan terms.

Procedure for Staff:

Check the insolvency order date against the loan start date.

If the insolvency order date is before the loan start date → the loan is not covered by that order.

If the insolvency order date is after the loan start date → follow the normal insolvency procedure (treat the loan as covered).

Record Details:

Note the insolvency order reference, date, and type in the account.

Record the loan start date for clarity.

Customer Communication:

If the loan is not covered by the insolvency order, explain clearly to the customer that the debt remains payable in full.

Example script:

“I can see that your insolvency order was made before this loan agreement started. This means your loan with us is not included in that arrangement, and you remain responsible for repayment under the original terms.”

Account Handling:

Continue managing the loan as normal (collections, interest, or settlement discussions) unless the customer later enters into a new insolvency arrangement that includes this loan.

Compliance Note:
It is important to distinguish between debts included in insolvency orders and those that fall outside due to being taken out afterwards. Always double-check dates and record them clearly.

documents.title: Cancelling a Schedule
documents.content:
Purpose:
To explain how agents can cancel a customer’s payment schedule and when this happens automatically.

Steps for Agents (Manual Cancellation):

Go to the account page of the customer’s account.

At the top of the page, locate the orange box titled “Schedules.”

Open the drop-down menu.

Select “Cancel Pay Plan.”

This will immediately cancel the active schedule on the account.

Automatic Cancellations:
A payment schedule will also cancel automatically if the account is moved into any of the following stages:

On Hold 1 Month

On Hold 2 Month

On Hold 3 Month

DM (Debt Management)

Vul (Vulnerability)

Pending Evidence

Important Notes for Staff:

Always confirm with the customer if they requested cancellation, and record the reason in the account notes.

Do not attempt to restart or amend a schedule without following the correct setup procedure.

documents.title: Customer Service Essentials
documents.content:
Purpose: Ensure all staff interact with customers in a professional, supportive, and compliant way.

Key Skills:

Tone: Always polite, empathetic, and professional, even in challenging conversations.

Active Listening: Let the customer speak, don’t interrupt, and acknowledge their concerns.

Plain English: Avoid jargon — explain things clearly and simply.

Empathy Statements: e.g. “I understand this must be difficult” or “Thank you for sharing that with me.”

Ownership: Take responsibility for helping resolve the query, even if you need to escalate.

Closing Calls/Emails: Summarise what was agreed and next steps.

documents.title: Dealing with Vulnerable Customers
documents.content:
Purpose: To handle calls where customers disclose difficulties such as illness, financial hardship, or other vulnerabilities.

Steps:

Listen carefully and acknowledge what the customer has said.

Reassure them we can pause or adapt support if needed.

Move the account with to on hold - Vulnerability, if you agree a hold and note the reason. 

Add a "must read note" to make other staff aware of potential vulnerbility (this will show at the top of the general page)

Task the account for a review (dependant on what is agreed with the customer)

Provide information on free debt advice services if appropriate.

USse vulnerbility tools if needed i.e TEXAS

Escalate to a manager (Zoe Quick) if position is complex and you are unsure of how to handle the situation.

documents.title: Handling Difficult Conversations
documents.content:
Purpose: To support staff when customers become upset, angry, or frustrated.

Top Tips:

Stay calm and professional — don’t match the customer’s tone.

Acknowledge their feelings: “I can hear you’re frustrated, let’s work through this together.”

Stick to facts and solutions, not emotions.

If the customer becomes abusive, politely warn them before ending the call.

Always record notes factually and without judgment.

documents.title: Understanding & Managing Customer Vulnerabilities
documents.content:
Purpose:
To help staff recognise and respond appropriately when customers disclose vulnerabilities, in line with Consumer Duty and treating customers fairly.

1. Health-Related Vulnerabilities

Examples: Physical disability, serious illness, mental health conditions, addiction, cognitive impairment.

How to Respond:

Show empathy and patience.

Offer to slow down the call or provide information in writing.

If needed, place account into VUL (Vulnerability) status.

Provide signposting to specialist support (e.g. debt charities, mental health helplines).

2. Financial Vulnerabilities

Examples: Job loss, reduced income, high cost of living, reliance on benefits, sudden financial shock (e.g. bereavement, separation).

How to Respond:

Explore affordable solutions (payment plans, short-term hold).

Place into On Hold stage if evidence is pending.

Remind them about free, impartial debt advice services.

Record notes clearly with context.

3. Situational Vulnerabilities

Examples: Bereavement, domestic abuse, caring responsibilities, divorce/separation, homelessness.

How to Respond:

Be sensitive to emotional impact.

Avoid pressing for immediate decisions.

Offer flexibility and note the account accordingly.

Escalate if safeguarding concerns arise (e.g. risk of harm).

4. Communication Barriers

Examples: Low literacy, English not first language, hearing or speech difficulties, limited access to digital tools.

How to Respond:

Adapt communication style — speak clearly, avoid jargon.

Offer alternative formats (email instead of phone, written confirmation).

Allow extra time on calls.

Record any preferences in account notes.

5. Age-Related Vulnerabilities

Examples: Elderly customers with reduced memory/understanding, very young customers with limited financial experience.

How to Respond:

Check understanding by asking the customer to repeat back.

Provide extra explanations where needed.

Be mindful of potential safeguarding concerns.

Escalate if exploitation or financial abuse is suspected.

6. Risk of Harm / Safeguarding

Examples: Suicidal thoughts, domestic abuse, threats of violence, immediate safety risks.

How to Respond:

Stay calm and listen.

If risk of immediate harm, follow emergency safeguarding procedure (e.g. contact emergency services if disclosure suggests life is in danger).

Escalate to a manager straight away.

Record facts only, not opinions.

Key Staff Reminders

Always note the vulnerability in the system using MUST READ NOTE and/or place into On Hold-Vulnerble stage, with the reason stated clearly.

Never judge or dismiss what the customer discloses.

Provide reassurance and explain what support options are available.

Escalate if unsure — better to check than mishandle a vulnerable customer.

documents.title: Vulnerabilities & Tools for Staff
documents.content:
Purpose:
To help staff identify, record, and manage customer vulnerabilities consistently and sensitively, using recognised industry tools.

1. Health-Related Vulnerabilities

Examples: Long-term illness, disability, mental health, addiction.

Tool: TEXAS Protocol (for handling disclosures)

Thank the customer for sharing.

Explain how the information will be used.

Xplicit consent — ask if you can record/share it internally.

Ask relevant questions (how it affects finances, any support needed).

Signpost to help (e.g. StepChange, Mind, Citizens Advice).

2. Financial Vulnerabilities

Examples: Job loss, reduced income, benefit reliance, cost-of-living pressures.

Tool: IDEA (for understanding impact)

Impact — how is the situation affecting them financially?

Duration — is it short-term, long-term, or permanent?

Experience — have they managed something similar before?

Adjustment — what support or changes do they need?

3. Situational Vulnerabilities

Examples: Bereavement, caring duties, domestic abuse, separation.

Tool: CARERS (for carers or dependent-related issues)

Check circumstances sensitively.

Assess how caring impacts finances/time.

Record disclosure with consent.

Explain available support.

Refer to advice organisations if appropriate.

Support flexibly (e.g. pauses, payment plans).

documents.title: Using IDEA with Customers
documents.content:
Purpose:
IDEA helps agents understand the customer’s situation more deeply when they disclose a vulnerability. It breaks the conversation into four areas: Impact, Duration, Experience, Adjustment.

I – Impact

What impact is the vulnerability having on their finances or ability to manage the account?

✅ Example questions:

“How is this situation affecting your ability to make payments right now?”

“Has this change impacted your income or expenses?”

✅ Example notes:

Customer unable to work due to surgery, now on reduced sick pay.

Customer’s mental health makes budgeting difficult.

D – Duration

Is the situation temporary, long-term, or permanent?

✅ Example questions:

“Do you expect this to change soon, or is it ongoing?”

“Has your GP or adviser said how long you may be in this situation?”

✅ Example notes:

Customer expects to return to work in 3 months after recovery.

Customer has long-term disability, likely ongoing.

E – Experience

Has the customer been through this before, and how did they manage?

✅ Example questions:

“Have you had to manage something like this before?”

“What’s helped you cope with your finances in the past?”

✅ Example notes:

Customer has been through redundancy before, relied on payment holidays.

Customer has never been in financial difficulty before, feels anxious and unsure.

A – Adjustment

What changes, support, or solutions are needed now?

✅ Example questions:

“What would help make things more manageable for you right now?”

“Would a short-term hold or reduced payment plan give you some breathing space?”

✅ Example notes:

Customer requests 2-month payment hold until benefits start.

Customer would like smaller instalments for 6 months.

Putting It All Together – Example Call Notes

IDEA applied:

Impact: Customer off work due to broken leg, income dropped to statutory sick pay.

Duration: Doctor says recovery expected in 12 weeks.

Experience: Customer previously managed using savings, but has none left now.

Adjustment: Customer requests a temporary hold on payments until return to work.

documents.title: Using CARERS with Customers
documents.content:
Purpose:
The CARERS tool helps agents handle disclosures where customers are carers, or where caring responsibilities are affecting their finances and account management.

C – Check circumstances sensitively

Understand the customer’s caring situation without being intrusive.

✅ Example questions:

“Can I ask a little more about your caring responsibilities, so I can understand how it affects your account?”

“Who do you provide care for, and how much time does this take each day?”

✅ Example notes:

Customer caring full-time for elderly parent with dementia.

Customer provides part-time care for disabled child alongside work.

A – Assess how caring impacts finances/time

Does caring reduce income, increase expenses, or affect their ability to make payments?

✅ Example questions:

“Does your caring role affect your ability to work or manage finances?”

“Do you have extra costs linked to caring, such as travel or equipment?”

✅ Example notes:

Customer reduced to part-time work due to caring role.

Customer has increased household costs, no spare income.

R – Record disclosure with consent

Always ask before noting sensitive details.

✅ Example script:

“Would you be happy for me to make a note of this on your account, so we can make sure we support you properly?”

✅ Example notes:

Consent given. Recorded customer caring for disabled child; limited availability during working hours.

E – Explain available support

Tell the customer how we can help manage their account fairly.

✅ Example script:

“We can look at putting your account on hold, adjusting your payment plan, or finding a schedule that works around your circumstances.”

R – Refer to advice organisations if appropriate

Signpost to specialist support.

✅ Examples:

Carers UK (www.carersuk.org
)

Citizens Advice

Local authority carers’ services

✅ Example script:

“There are organisations that can support carers with financial and emotional help — would you like me to share their details?”

S – Support flexibly

Put in place adjustments to help the customer manage.

✅ Examples:

Place account into On Hold (VUL) while circumstances are reviewed.

Offer flexible repayment dates that match benefit/payment cycles.

Allow more time for evidence if requested.

Putting It All Together – Example Call Notes

CARERS applied:

Check: Customer provides daily care for disabled spouse.

Assess: Reduced working hours, lower income, increased household costs.

Record: Consent given; noted in account.

Explain: Advised account could be placed on hold pending review.

Refer: Provided details for Carers UK.

Support: Account placed into VUL stage; repayment plan to be reviewed in 3 months.

documents.title: Abbreviations Log
documents.content:
Purpose:
Quick reference for staff to understand common abbreviations used in customer accounts, communications, and internal processes.

Account Stages & Holds

On Hold 1/2/3 – Account temporarily paused for review.

DM – Debt Management hold.

VUL – Vulnerable customer hold.

IVA – Individual Voluntary Arrangement.

DRO – Debt Relief Order.

BNK – Bankruptcy.

Processes & Actions

CB – Call Back.

LM – Left Message.

NA – No Answer.

CATC – Collection Action To Continue.

ES – Early Settlement.

RTW – Right To Withdraw.

Customer & Payment Terms

Cust – Customer.

BT – Bank Transfer.

CPA – Continuous Payment Authority.

Paym – Payment.

CIF – Clear In Full.

Clr – Cleared.

mnth – Month.

rec'd – Received.

Vulnerability Tools & Protocols

TEXAS – Thank, Explain, eXplicit consent, Ask, Signpost.

IDEA – Impact, Duration, Experience, Adjustment.

CARERS – Check, Assess, Record, Explain, Refer, Support.

BRUCE – Behaviour, Remember, Understand, Check, Explore.

Credit & Collections References

CRS – Credit Resource Solutions.

UKS – UK Search.

DRA – Digital DRA.

Interest & Balances

OS – Outstanding Balance (principal + accrued interest).

INT – Daily Interest applied (0.8% per day of outstanding principal).
